title: Obstacle Training Course - Comprehensive Test
description: Comprehensive test covering NCC obstacle course training, obstacle types, negotiation techniques, safety measures, and benefits

questions.text: How many obstacles are there in the standard NCC obstacle course?
questions.explanation: The Standard Obstacle Course that the NCC cadets are required to negotiate consists of ten obstacles.

questions.text: What is the approximate distance between each obstacle in the course?
questions.explanation: Each obstacle is placed at a distance of about 30 feet from each other in the standard obstacle course.

questions.text: What is the height of the Straight Balance obstacle from the ground?
questions.explanation: The Straight Balance is a wooden plank 1½ feet above ground level that cadets cross while balancing.

questions.text: How should a cadet cross the Straight Balance obstacle?

options.b: Running with arms open for balance

questions.explanation: A cadet crosses the Straight Balance obstacle running, keeping his arms open and balancing his body.

questions.text: What is the height of the Clear Jump obstacle from the ground?
questions.explanation: The Clear Jump wooden beam is 2½ feet from the ground, and cadets must jump over it without touching it.

questions.text: What is the key requirement when crossing the Clear Jump obstacle?

options.a: Touching the beam with one hand
options.b: Jumping without touching any part of the body

questions.explanation: Cadet has to jump over the Clear Jump without touching or using any part of the body on the beam.

questions.text: What is the length of the Zig-Zag Balance obstacle?
questions.explanation: The Zig-Zag Balance is a wooden beam 18 feet in length, constructed in a zig-zag manner 1½ feet above ground.

questions.text: What is the height of the High Wall obstacle?
questions.explanation: The High Wall is a 6 feet high brick wall with plaster on both sides that cadets must climb over.

questions.text: What is the correct technique for crossing the High Wall?

options.a: Run, jump, kick the wall with one leg, use hands to push over

questions.explanation: For crossing the High Wall, a cadet has to run, jump, kick the wall with one leg, take leap putting both hands on the wall, push body upwards and jump over.

questions.text: How many ditches are there in the Double Ditch obstacle?
questions.explanation: The Double Ditch obstacle is composed of two ditches separated by a small gap of approximately 9-12 inches.

questions.text: What is the technique for crossing the Double Ditch?

options.a: Jump across both ditches in one leap
options.b: Jump first ditch, place foot on gap, jump second ditch

questions.explanation: The cadet must jump across the two ditches by jumping over the first ditch, placing one foot on the gap and jumping across the second ditch.

questions.text: What is the height of the Right Hand Vault and Left Hand Vault obstacles?
questions.explanation: Both Right Hand Vault and Left Hand Vault are wooden structures 3½ feet above the ground.

questions.text: What is the main difference between Right Hand Vault and Left Hand Vault?
questions.explanation: Right Hand Vault uses right hand as support, while Left Hand Vault uses left hand as support on the beam.

questions.text: How many beams does the Gate Vault obstacle have?
questions.explanation: The Gate Vault has two beams at heights of 3 feet and 5 feet respectively, both 18 feet long.

questions.text: What is the correct technique for Gate Vault?

options.a: Hold upper beam with both hands, put feet on 3ft gate and jump across
options.d: Use only the lower beam for support

questions.explanation: For Gate Vault, one must hold the upper beam with both hands and put feet on the 3ft gate, then jump across.

questions.text: What is the height of the Ramp obstacle?
questions.explanation: The Ramp is 4½ feet high, 15 feet long and 18 feet wide sloppy hillock that cadets must climb and jump from.

questions.text: How should a cadet land after jumping from the Ramp?

options.b: On both feet in a pit

questions.explanation: After reaching the top of the Ramp, the cadet takes a long jump and lands on a pit on both feet.

questions.text: Which safety measure is recommended for obstacle training?

options.b: Training first in PT dress, later with packs and weapon

questions.explanation: Training should be given first in PT dress, later on with packs and weapon to ensure proper progression and safety.

questions.text: What type of obstacles and areas should be avoided during training?

options.b: Wet and slippery obstacles and areas

questions.explanation: Wet and slippery obstacles and areas should be avoided to prevent accidents and injuries during training.

questions.text: What qualification should instructors have for obstacle training?
questions.explanation: Obstacles should be done under supervision of qualified instructors using correct techniques only.

questions.text: Which of these is NOT mentioned as a benefit of obstacle course training?
questions.explanation: Benefits include physical fitness, agility, mental robustness, coordination, risk-taking ability, problem-solving skills, and team spirit - but not cooking skills.

questions.text: What qualities does obstacle training help to develop in cadets?
questions.explanation: Obstacle training infuses courage, patience and makes cadets physically fit and mentally robust.

questions.text: In which camp is intensive obstacle training especially given to cadets?
questions.explanation: Intensive training is given to cadets in the camps especially in Thal Sainik Camp.

questions.text: What materials are used for constructing the obstacles?
questions.explanation: The obstacles are constructed of wood, bricks, concrete and mud depending upon the structure.

questions.text: What is the primary purpose of obstacle training in NCC?

options.a: To make cadets physically tough and develop confidence

questions.explanation: Obstacle course training makes cadets physically tough but also develops high degree of confidence and inculcates qualities of patience and courage.
